articles.headline: When Markets Plunge, Blame Central Banks
articles.snippet: As emerging stock markets submerge, the analysts have figured out who is to blame: the big central banks.
articles.abstract: As emerging stock markets submerge, the analysts have figured out who is to blame: the big central banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS emerging stock markets submerge, the analysts have figured out who is to blame: the big central banks.

articles.headline: The New Face of Solidarity
articles.snippet: The nation's private sector is divided into two very different labor movements, the declining manufacturing unions and the expanding service sector.
articles.abstract: The nation's private sector is divided into two very different labor movements, the declining manufacturing unions and the expanding service sector.
articles.lead_paragraph: Manuel Alvarez is the type of worker that service-sector unions are eager to attract. After 11 years as a houseman at the Hilton Hotel at Los Angeles International Airport, he earns $9.95 an hour, about $20,000 a year.

articles.headline: U.S. Portrayal Helps Flesh Out Zarqawi's Heir
articles.snippet: American military officers released a photograph and details of the man they say succeeded Abu Musab al-Zarqawi in Iraq.
articles.abstract: American military officers released a photograph and details of the man they say succeeded Abu Musab al-Zarqawi in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 15 — American military officers on Thursday put a face on the new chief of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, releasing a photograph and details of the man they say succeeded Abu Musab al-Zarqawi after he was killed in an airstrike last week.

articles.headline: Gates to Cede Software Reins
articles.snippet: The move, analysts said, points to the changes sweeping the software industry.
articles.abstract: The move, analysts said, points to the changes sweeping the software industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash., June 15 — Three decades after he started Microsoft with the dream of placing a personal computer in every home and business, Bill Gates said Thursday that he would leave his day-to-day role there in two years.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Stocks Soar as Fed Chief Eases Fears on Inflation
articles.snippet: Stocks gained for a second day after five tumultuous weeks in which they gave back all of their gains for the year.
articles.abstract: Stocks gained for a second day after five tumultuous weeks in which they gave back all of their gains for the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Share prices turned up sharply yesterday in a broad rally that was fed by tame inflation remarks from the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, even as it added to concerns about increasing volatility in the market.

articles.headline: U.S.-Style Pay Packages Are All the Rage in Europe
articles.snippet: The shift is coming from the increased use of international comparisons, which are not really all that international.
articles.abstract: The shift is coming from the increased use of international comparisons, which are not really all that international.
articles.lead_paragraph: Along with hip-hop and Hollywood movies, Europeans are eagerly importing another American phenomenon: soaring pay packages for chief executives.

articles.headline: In Oil-Rich Angola, Cholera Preys Upon Poorest
articles.snippet: Luanda's slums are now the center of one of the worst cholera epidemics to strike Africa in nearly a decade.
articles.abstract: Luanda's slums are now the center of one of the worst cholera epidemics to strike Africa in nearly a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUANDA, Angola, June 10 — In a nation whose multibillion-dollar oil boom should arguably make its people rich enough to drink Evian, the water that many in this capital depend on goes by a less fancy name: Bengo.

articles.headline: Stocks Soar as Fed Chief Eases Fears on Inflation
articles.snippet: Share prices turned up sharply yesterday in a broad rally that was fed by tame inflation remarks from the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, even as it added to concerns about increasing volatility in the market.      Stocks gained for a s...
articles.abstract: Share prices turned up sharply yesterday in a broad rally that was fed by tame inflation remarks from the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, even as it added to concerns about increasing volatility in the market.      Stocks gained for a second day after five tumultuous weeks in which they gave back all of their gains for the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Share prices turned up sharply yesterday in a broad rally that was fed by tame inflation remarks from the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, even as it added to concerns about increasing volatility in the market.

articles.headline: Partisan Fight Over Iraq War Erupts on Hill
articles.snippet: The House and the Senate engaged in angry, intensely partisan debate on Thursday over the war in Iraq, as Republicans sought to rally support for the Bush administration's policies and exploit Democratic divisions in an election year shadowed by u...
articles.abstract: The House and the Senate engaged in angry, intensely partisan debate on Thursday over the war in Iraq, as Republicans sought to rally support for the Bush administration's policies and exploit Democratic divisions in an election year shadowed by unease over the war.     It was one of the sharpest legislative clashes yet over the three-year-old conflict, and it came after three days in which President Bush and his aides had sought to portray Iraq as moving gradually toward a stable, functioning democracy, and to portray Democrats as lacking the will to see the conflict through to victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 15 - The House and the Senate engaged in angry, intensely partisan debate on Thursday over the war in Iraq, as Republicans sought to rally support for the Bush administration's policies and exploit Democratic divisions in an election year shadowed by unease over the war.
articles.byline: By Robin Toner and Kate Zernike

articles.headline: U.S. Portrayal Helps Flesh Out Zarqawi's Heir
articles.snippet: American military officers on Thursday put a face on the new chief of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, releasing a photograph and details of the man they say succeeded Abu Musab al-Zarqawi after he was killed in an airstrike last week.      In a news brie...
articles.abstract: American military officers on Thursday put a face on the new chief of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, releasing a photograph and details of the man they say succeeded Abu Musab al-Zarqawi after he was killed in an airstrike last week.      In a news briefing, Maj. Gen. William B. Caldwell IV, the American military spokesman here, identified Mr. Zarqawi's successor as Abu Ayyub al-Masri, an Egyptian who he said had trained in one of the terrorist camps in Afghanistan run by Al Qaeda in 1999.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 15 - American military officers on Thursday put a face on the new chief of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, releasing a photograph and details of the man they say succeeded Abu Musab al-Zarqawi after he was killed in an airstrike last week.

articles.headline: In Oil-Rich Angola, Cholera Preys Upon Poorest
articles.snippet: In a nation whose multibillion-dollar oil boom should arguably make its people rich enough to drink Evian, the water that many in this capital depend on goes by a less fancy name: Bengo.     The Bengo River passes north of here, its waters dark wi...
articles.abstract: In a nation whose multibillion-dollar oil boom should arguably make its people rich enough to drink Evian, the water that many in this capital depend on goes by a less fancy name: Bengo.     The Bengo River passes north of here, its waters dark with grit, its banks strewn with garbage.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUANDA, Angola, June 10 - In a nation whose multibillion-dollar oil boom should arguably make its people rich enough to drink Evian, the water that many in this capital depend on goes by a less fancy name: Bengo.

articles.headline: Big Airlines to Increase Some Fares
articles.snippet: Add this to the growing list of headaches for travelers: Fares keep rising.      Most of the nation's largest airlines said yesterday that they would raise prices for many last-minute tickets.
articles.abstract: Add this to the growing list of headaches for travelers: Fares keep rising.      Most of the nation's largest airlines said yesterday that they would raise prices for many last-minute tickets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Add this to the growing list of headaches for travelers: Fares keep rising.

articles.headline: Gates to Cede Software Reins
articles.snippet: Three decades after he started Microsoft with the dream of placing a personal computer in every home and business, Bill Gates said Thursday that he would leave his day-to-day role there in two years.      He will shift his energies to the Bill and...
articles.abstract: Three decades after he started Microsoft with the dream of placing a personal computer in every home and business, Bill Gates said Thursday that he would leave his day-to-day role there in two years.      He will shift his energies to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, which his Microsoft fortune has made the world's largest philanthropic organization, dedicated to health and education issues, especially in poor nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash., June 15 - Three decades after he started Microsoft with the dream of placing a personal computer in every home and business, Bill Gates said Thursday that he would leave his day-to-day role there in two years.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: The New Face of Solidarity
articles.snippet: Manuel Alvarez is the type of worker that service-sector unions are eager to attract. After 11 years as a houseman at the Hilton Hotel at Los Angeles International Airport, he earns $9.95 an hour, about $20,000 a year.     ''It's not enough to liv...
articles.abstract: Manuel Alvarez is the type of worker that service-sector unions are eager to attract. After 11 years as a houseman at the Hilton Hotel at Los Angeles International Airport, he earns $9.95 an hour, about $20,000 a year.     ''It's not enough to live on,'' said Mr. Alvarez, an immigrant from Mexico who vacuums halls and flips mattresses. ''I go to two churches each week to pick up donated food.'' On his days off, he collects bottles and cans for the deposit, adding $200 a month to his income. His hope is to join a union, and soon.
articles.lead_paragraph: Manuel Alvarez is the type of worker that service-sector unions are eager to attract. After 11 years as a houseman at the Hilton Hotel at Los Angeles International Airport, he earns $9.95 an hour, about $20,000 a year.

articles.headline: A New Trade Envoy, With a Battle on Her Hands
articles.snippet: Not many new Cabinet members take office with a deadline of six weeks or so to succeed or fail in their jobs. But that was what Susan C. Schwab faced Thursday when she was sworn in as the new United States trade representative.      President Bush...
articles.abstract: Not many new Cabinet members take office with a deadline of six weeks or so to succeed or fail in their jobs. But that was what Susan C. Schwab faced Thursday when she was sworn in as the new United States trade representative.      President Bush praised his new envoy on Thursday as ''a good, hard negotiator.'' Still, she faces long odds as trade diplomats struggle to salvage a global accord that the Bush administration hopes will be one of its signal economic achievements.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 15 - Not many new Cabinet members take office with a deadline of six weeks or so to succeed or fail in their jobs. But that was what Susan C. Schwab faced Thursday when she was sworn in as the new United States trade representative.

articles.headline: U.S.-Style Pay Packages Are All the Rage in Europe
articles.snippet: Along with hip-hop and Hollywood movies, Europeans are eagerly importing another American phenomenon: soaring pay packages for chief executives.      For decades, Europeans were far more restrained than Americans when it came to rewarding the boss...
articles.abstract: Along with hip-hop and Hollywood movies, Europeans are eagerly importing another American phenomenon: soaring pay packages for chief executives.      For decades, Europeans were far more restrained than Americans when it came to rewarding the boss. Now, executives overseas are less inhibited about asking for American-style compensation. And often they are getting their wish.
articles.lead_paragraph: Along with hip-hop and Hollywood movies, Europeans are eagerly importing another American phenomenon: soaring pay packages for chief executives.

articles.headline: When Markets Plunge, Blame Central Banks
articles.snippet: AS emerging stock markets submerge, the analysts have figured out who is to blame: the big central banks.     Were collapses really caused by excessive efforts of the Federal Reserve Board and the European Central Bank to fight inflation, or by th...
articles.abstract: AS emerging stock markets submerge, the analysts have figured out who is to blame: the big central banks.     Were collapses really caused by excessive efforts of the Federal Reserve Board and the European Central Bank to fight inflation, or by the Bank of Japan talking of ending its zero interest rate policy?
articles.lead_paragraph: AS emerging stock markets submerge, the analysts have figured out who is to blame: the big central banks.
